1.14.text:
So this is what one ‑‑ no, 10,000 women
look like! Wow.

8.58.text:
It's a real honor to be here today to be asked
to address all of you women who understand

16.44.text:
how important it is to step outside your comfort
zone to better yourselves and the communities

22.03.text:
you live in. It is also a particular privilege
to share the stage with Mrs. Hillary Clinton,

30.08.text:
who will be coming after me, literally a leader
among men.

44.77.text:
My mommy is here, my number one cheerleader,
and my amazing managers who have helped make

56.60.text:
everything that has happened in my life in
the last two years possible. Thank you.

65.51.text:
I want to thank Imanie and Andrea for introducing
me ‑‑ it is terrifying to be up here;

71.14.text:
and they did so so sweetly ‑‑ and also
for paying it forward. This conference opened

77.92.text:
up their eyes and their hearts and they allowed
it to change the course of their feet and

85.28.text:
in turn changed the lives of other women.
Thank you for that, and may we all be so receptive

91.03.text:
to life's opportunities.
I was asked to speak today in the spring.

101.11.text:
It was a very busy time and I was still coming
down off of the whole award season whirlwind,

108.36.text:
and I have to admit I agreed to it only because
it seemed so far, far away.

115.96.text:
But you know, with things that are far, far
away, with time, they get nearer and nearer,

121.45.text:
and as they got nearer and nearer I got more
afraid they wouldn't know what to say, and

128.40.text:
then I thought, that's it! I will talk about
overcoming fear in order to achieve your goals

133.37.text:
and your dreams.
And I thought it was perfect. But then, of

137.36.text:
course, I was crippled by the fear of talking
about my fear. (:‑)

142.76.text:
I tried to find other people's examples that
illustrate the things that I have learned

150.14.text:
about dealing with fear, but I couldn't remember
any of them well enough to borrow them. I

155.51.text:
thought I would hire someone to write my speech
but then they'd know everything about me including

160.31.text:
my neuroses, but then I thought I should find
another thing to talk about. But then I was

168.06.text:
doing that actor thing to hide behind something.
That is what we do, tell the truth by pretending

174.82.text:
to be someone else. So I thought I would tell
you how I decided to be an actor in the first

185.43.text:
place.
I would like to dedicate this speech to my

188.86.text:
sister who at this time is struggling with
finding her purpose. I have three sisters,

195.57.text:
so I hope I haven't called anyone out.
I meant to write to her. I have meant to call

201.73.text:
her, but you know our modern lifestyles can
keep us so far away from the people we love

206.38.text:
most, and it seems that the more ways there
are for us to communicate, the harder it is

211.71.text:
for us to do. So by sharing this with you
today, I hope to kill two birds with one stone.

219.82.text:
Dreams: The dictionary defines them as a series
of thoughts, images, and sensations occurring

229.23.text:
in our brains when we are asleep or relaxing.
The dreaming I would like to speak to is that

236.12.text:
glimpse of the thing you want to do that would
make you feel most alive, a dream as a portal

243.53.text:
to your purpose.
My dream was to be an actor from when I was

248.43.text:
really young, but I didn't always know it.
Before I could call myself an actor, I had

253.61.text:
a lot of stuff to do. I had to unchain myself
from indecision. I had to cut through fear,

260.83.text:
the fear of going after my dream, jump over
my own ego and embrace vulnerability, and

268.16.text:
confront a great deal of imposter syndrome.
The first step to becoming an actor was to

276.14.text:
choose it for myself. Now, I am very indecisive.
I am a Pisces, astrologically predisposed

283.54.text:
to not being able to make up my mind. I accept
that. But being an actor would be more difficult

292.75.text:
because I was raised in Nairobi, Kenya, in
the 1980s where acting was not a viable career

300.97.text:
path. Although making believe when I was little,
nobody around me was acting for a living.

311.23.text:
In school it was not a profession you learned
about. You could be a lawyer, a doctor, businessman

316.77.text:
or woman, secretary, policeman or woman, teacher,
politician, but actor was never on the list.

324.55.text:
It didn't help that at the time, in the '80s
we only had one TV, owned by the state, and

330.46.text:
it had boring programming for a child. Government
propaganda. We witnessed which school the

339.15.text:
president distributed packets of milk to,
which church he attended last Sunday. So my

348.00.text:
primary source for entertainment and performance,
the world of performance, became my cassette

355.71.text:
tapes my cousins dubbed of American television
and brought back home.

361.22.text:
I was enraptured by things like Kids Incorporated,
Menuto, Different Strokes. But the characters

370.66.text:
I saw, they all had strange accents and lived
in a far‑away land called America.

376.72.text:
In the '90s we got our second TV station,
and this one aired 95 percent foreign programming.

383.88.text:
I watched Rosa from Mexico, Neighbors from
Australia, and East Enders from the U.K. So

391.68.text:
while my imagination grew and my passion for
performance expanded, it still was not a reflection

398.63.text:
of what was realistically possible for me
to dream for myself.

405.08.text:
But when I watched The Color Purple and saw
Oprah and Whoopie Goldberg, a seed was planted

412.34.text:
in my heart to be an actor, but I dared not
water it in public. See, being an actor was

419.87.text:
not an honorable thing to do, especially for
a politician's daughter. It was something

426.19.text:
a child did and grown‑up children did, but
not anyone else.

431.44.text:
I pursued acting opportunities on the side,
and as long as it was extracurricular and

437.93.text:
not my focus, it felt safe and acceptable.
Mind you, my parents never put any pressure

445.55.text:
on me to be one thing or another, but it was
the expectation from the larger society that

450.08.text:
kept me ashamed of the real desire in any
heart.

454.61.text:
Soon enough I was in such self‑denial that
I didn't believe that I wanted to be an actor

461.03.text:
after all. Then what did I want to be? As
I grew older, I grew more and more confused

466.78.text:
about what I wanted from myself. And at some
point in my adolescence, the question, what

472.78.text:
do you want to be when you grow up, seemed
to be the only question on every adult's lips.

477.36.text:
There is so much pressure to define ourselves
by one thing when we are younger, and I disagree

483.45.text:
with that. We can and should be able to define
ourselves as many things ‑‑ especially

490.50.text:
children.
Anyway, I took to answering that question

495.13.text:
spontaneously in the hope that one day I would
land on a gold mine of truth and, by accident,

502.66.text:
finally know what my life was to be about.
Entertainment lawyer! Environmentalist! Botanist!

513.62.text:
By the time I got to undergrad in Hampshire
College in the U.S. here in Massachusetts,

519.68.text:
I was still looking for that practical, that
useful, viable career path, the profitable

526.19.text:
type, the assured type.
I went for the closest thing to acting that

530.82.text:
I could think of, Film Studies, because I
figured it was better to want to hold the

536.68.text:
camera than to want to play in front of it.
But I continued to act after school, and once

543.27.text:
that was done, that chapter, though I learned
a lot and have been passionate about my education,

549.19.text:
I still did not feel that my life was in the
right gear.

553.63.text:
I moved back to Kenya in a state of personal
crisis, still wondering what my life was to

559.32.text:
be about. I was disappointed that at age 25
I was still feeling lost and confused, and

566.86.text:
I was worried that at the rate I was going,
I would never figure it out.

572.95.text:
My indecision and self‑denial were becoming
healthy breeding grounds for fear. I started

581.14.text:
writing people I respected in Kenya, and as
they dispelled their advice I sat across from

587.00.text:
them and I felt so envious of their clarity
and their ability to pursue their dreams.

593.94.text:
Why couldn't I be like that? I coveted their
dreams.

597.97.text:
When I met with a director, I wanted to be
a director. When I met with a producer, I

602.21.text:
wanted to be a producer. I even met with a
copyright lawyer and thought that was a dream

606.88.text:
for me. (:‑)
I looked for all sorts of jobs that were related ‑‑

613.24.text:
journalist, TV anchor, emcee. Nothing worked,
nothing stuck.

617.46.text:
Author Marty Reuben said when people don't
know what they want, they don't act.

627.60.text:
There was indecision until I stopped running
away from myself and listened to myself. I

637.27.text:
took a time out, silenced the voices, stopped
the chatter, and really thought about what

643.97.text:
would make me happy.
I admitted it ‑‑ first to myself, and

651.72.text:
then out loud ‑‑ that what I wanted more
than anything was to make believe for a living!

662.99.text:
I wept, as I am doing now. Because it was
so hard!

675.06.text:
[APPLAUSE].
Seems like this is what I do best really.

681.81.text:
[LAUGHTER]
I wept because it was so hard to admit that

686.70.text:
I wanted to be something so improbable and
impractical for a Kenyan like myself. It felt

694.53.text:
like a lofty pipe dream, really. But deep
down I was overjoyed because I was finally

701.01.text:
speaking the truth about what made me feel
most alive! And it wasn't real until I shared

708.04.text:
it.
John Lennon put it best: A dream you dream

711.81.text:
alone is only a dream. A dream you dream together
is a reality.

718.56.text:
Once it is uttered and you have taken ownership
of it, the destination is taken care of and

724.67.text:
the journey can begin. So I got down to the
most important work, figuring out what steps

731.28.text:
would get me to being an actor, the actor
I wanted badly to be. I had an action plan,

737.90.text:
something to work towards ‑‑ getting
into the Yale School of Drama for acting training.

743.28.text:
To go after my goal to attend the Yale School
of Drama would mean I had to confront my fear

749.99.text:
of failure, of not being good enough. I knew
it was a good acting program, and I wanted

756.76.text:
to be at the best program possible if I could
give this acting thing a fair shot.

763.29.text:
But we didn't have a theater library in Kenya.
For the audition I worked on one monologue

776.01.text:
that I picked up in a class when I was 12,
and a monologue from Juliet when I was 14.

784.15.text:
Mind you I am 25 at this point. I had no other
choices so I made do.

790.50.text:
As I boarded the plane to the U.S., there
were naysayers in my head telling me I shouldn't

797.87.text:
even bother. More than 900 people audition
for 15 spots each year. Yet there was a part

805.63.text:
of me that knew I could do it, even when the
part of me that said it was impossible was

811.05.text:
louder.
Our dreams arise from our imaginations. They

816.11.text:
belong to us. We owe it to ourselves to try
and realize them. To encourage myself, I wrote

822.35.text:
in my diary on the 23rd of August 2008. I
have this dream to be an actor and it dwarfs

830.66.text:
me, but it is my dream, goddamn it. I dreamed
it up. How can what I dreamed up defeat me?

840.31.text:
Then I got into Yale, this prestigious school
where actors like Meryl Streep and Angela

847.12.text:
Bassett went. Meryl Streep is so legendary
in Yale we referred to her as "the Streep."

856.21.text:
(:‑)
I was overjoyed. This was an opportunity to

861.15.text:
immerse myself in my craft surrounded by people
of equal and greater talent. They had accepted

869.15.text:
me and I had to prove to them and myself that
I deserved to be there.

875.30.text:
I couldn't afford to fail. I had traveled
too far for that. And I had defied what was

880.69.text:
expected of me in my community. Too much was
at stake. My dream was in motion, and it was

886.13.text:
very much in my own hands now.
And I had every intention to work hard and

891.63.text:
excel at everything I did. But I would very
quickly learn that in acting school, things

897.96.text:
weren't that straightforward. Acting is not
like math, where there is only one correct

903.45.text:
answer to the problem and once you have figured
out the formula, you are all set. In acting,

909.75.text:
like in life, sometimes coming up with the
wrong answer to the problem is the best way

914.47.text:
to figure out the formula for yourself.
In acting school, you are expected to fail

921.07.text:
and fail publicly a lot. It is the constant
exposure to failure that frees you from the

928.94.text:
strongholds of the ego and allows you to embrace
vulnerability, and it is in embracing vulnerability

936.64.text:
that you can surprise yourself in performance
and share something really special about human

942.65.text:
nature.
I will give you an example. Imagine now that

947.91.text:
you've been singled out from this crowd just
as you are. You are told that your goal is

953.44.text:
to make everybody laugh. The instructions
are to leave the room and return with enthusiasm

960.78.text:
and do something great without having a clue
what that might be, and you can't use words

966.80.text:
or props or anything.
Now, I don't know about you, but that terrifies

971.92.text:
me, especially because laughter is the one
thing that an audience never lies about; they

977.80.text:
only give it to you when they are really tickled.
This is an exercise from a clown class at

983.68.text:
Yale. Now, not the painted clown with the
painted face and red nose and big shoes and

990.92.text:
baggy trousers that you find at a circus.
No. The clown I'm talking about is the simple,

998.19.text:
innocent fool that lives inside all of us,
the child within us that we spend most of

1004.00.text:
our lives hiding under layers of intelligence,
sensibilities, social cool, the one who gets

1011.84.text:
great joy in making others happy and finds
the fun in turning off and on a lightbulb

1020.29.text:
and is devastated by the pop of a balloon.
There is nothing as embarrassing and uncomfortable

1029.94.text:
as trying to make people laugh and hearing
nothing but silence in response.

1035.42.text:
When it was my turn to get up and do the exercise,
I tried all sorts of buffoonery. I flapped

1041.23.text:
my arms like a bird, I rolled on the floor,
I jumped up and down. I didn't believe I was

1048.51.text:
particularly funny, and I was desperate to
find something to hide behind. I was fresh

1054.74.text:
out of ideas and there had still not been
a single laugh in the room.

1060.06.text:
Eventually my teacher called me out. Chris
Faze. He said: You have failed, Lupita, haven't

1066.83.text:
you?
And at that point, I let it all go and broke

1071.49.text:
down and cried, audibly. It was only then
that everyone in the room burst out laughing!

1081.64.text:
[LAUGHTER]
Because I had finally allowed myself to be

1085.23.text:
honest and truthful and open with them. My
inner fool came out to play, only once I had

1093.23.text:
put my ego aside.
And so it was not until I had opened myself

1099.09.text:
up to the possibility of failing that I was
able to find success in clown class. Without

1105.65.text:
the possibility of being bad, you will never
be extraordinary. So I resolved to operate

1112.04.text:
from a sense of self that was louder than
my critic and faster than my worry. It is

1117.36.text:
only in that space that you can truly be free
and innovate.

1123.27.text:
Right before I graduated, the opportunity
to play Patsey was offered to me. After a

1128.84.text:
rigorous audition period, when Steve McQueen,
the director, called me to give me the part,

1133.98.text:
I remember I sat down on the pavement, overjoyed
and horrified by the prospect of working alongside

1141.03.text:
such seasoned artists. It was a dream come
true, but the saboteur in me believed that

1150.30.text:
it had come true to me too fast and that I
was not prepared for it. I was suffering from

1156.51.text:
typical "imposter syndrome," a pattern of
toxic thoughts that tells you how lucky you

1163.24.text:
are to have everybody fooled that you are
good at what you do!

1168.87.text:
Up until now. Your cover is about to be blown
this time, and they will know that you are

1176.59.text:
nothing but an imposter of talent.
Now, this was to be my first film, and judging

1185.95.text:
by the story and the people involved, I knew
it was no small potatoes. I couldn't possibly

1192.02.text:
get away with this one! It was a big deal.
And I wasn't! I felt small, like an underdog

1201.25.text:
dwarfed by everyone else in it. I had no experience
working on this level. I thought, how was

1208.25.text:
I supposed to act alongside Mr. Kinky Boots,
Mr. Magneto, and Troy himself? Who was I?

1216.29.text:
I was certain Steve had made a mistake and
he would fire me any day, and this was a real

1222.05.text:
fear of mine. It kept me up at night. In fact,
I didn't have a good night's rest from the

1226.42.text:
day I got the role until I wrapped on set.
Before I left to shoot the film I reached

1233.92.text:
out to a close friend of mine and classmate.
I asked her where all the abandon and courage

1241.13.text:
had disappeared to from all my time at Yale.
What had I learned, and why wouldn't it show

1247.22.text:
up when I needed it the most? My friend breathed
with me ‑‑ a good friend does that ‑‑

1254.27.text:
and she reminded me that it was all there,
that I needed to trust myself in order for

1260.62.text:
what I had learned to serve me. Patsey's point
of view had to matter to me more than my own.

1268.38.text:
She reminded me to lead not with my fear but
with my hope. When you are living on purpose,

1278.40.text:
the size of your human experience has got
nothing to do with it.

1285.43.text:
You see, when you are fearful, we spend more
time worrying about things that don't yet

1291.43.text:
exist and very little on building on what
already does. The solution is not to eradicate

1298.22.text:
fear. That would be nice, but fear does play
a role in keeping us safe. The solution is

1303.33.text:
to recognize fear with compassion and act
in spite of it. That is what courage is, after

1309.63.text:
all ‑‑ doing the thing you fear because
what you are to gain is worth the risk.

1314.17.text:
12 Years a Slave was worth the risk.
[APPLAUSE].

1324.14.text:
Now, after, the aftermath you have 12 Years
was something I could not have foreseen. I

1339.14.text:
definitely expected it to be an important
film, and the fantastic starting point for

1345.65.text:
me in my professional career, but I never
expected to receive all the recognition and

1351.41.text:
accolades that came with it. As such, I had
to make space in my heart to make space for

1358.14.text:
all the good stuff, and this was not easy.
They don't teach you that at school. I had

1364.85.text:
had a life of believing that I was afraid
of failure, and now here I was, faced squarely

1370.47.text:
with the fear of success. I was afraid of
success because I did not know what my lie

1377.49.text:
on the other side of it. With success comes
expectation and with that comes lofty responsibility.

1386.08.text:
Lately I have been afraid of not being able
to handle all these new expectations. I have

1394.09.text:
been afraid that my weaknesses have no place
in the world of these new‑found successes,

1400.81.text:
and I have to become a super version of me
to keep up with the versions of myself that

1405.53.text:
stare back at me from magazine covers.
To me, I have achieved the pinnacle of success

1412.92.text:
in my field, yet I still have the rest of
my life to go. It is at this point that I

1421.71.text:
have to constantly remind myself of how I
got here ‑‑ through hard work, faith,

1430.53.text:
daring to dream, and systematically slaying
the dragons that are self‑doubt, self‑hate,

1437.49.text:
and self‑denial. I must carry on on my personal
journey and dream more, dream again. They

1448.77.text:
disguise themselves, these dragons, every
time, as being different, but they are exactly

1457.36.text:
the same, and I must ultimately trust that
my life has equipped me with all the tools

1464.08.text:
and weapons, I need to deal with them. Your
life is equipping you now with all you need

1470.59.text:
to slay your dragons and realize your dreams
and goals.

1476.10.text:
More and more women today are coming alive,
diversifying their career path, defying the

1482.63.text:
narrow expectations the world has in place
for them. We continue to fight for equality,

1489.07.text:
for justice, for freedom, for compassion,
and we achieve the most when we are awakened

1497.50.text:
and responsive to the desires of our individual
hearts. It is then that we can really be a

1505.23.text:
part of a whole and share our tools to fulfill
the bigger picture of a better tomorrow.

1512.32.text:
Seven tools I offer you today. Recognize and
articulate your fears to yourself, then look

1519.38.text:
for what you love and articulate that to yourself
and others. Do this often, and your love will

1526.29.text:
grow stronger than your fear.
Two. Reach out to your stretcher bearers.

1534.88.text:
This is a concept I carried with me from high
school Bible teaching. It speaks of a time

1541.05.text:
when Jesus was teaching a crowd of people
that had come from all over. Some men came

1547.05.text:
late, carrying their paralyzed friend on a
stretcher. It was so crowded around Jesus

1552.97.text:
they decided to go up on the roof, take up
the tiles, and lower the man into the middle

1558.70.text:
of the crowd in front of Jesus. When Jesus
saw their faith and how much love they had,

1564.86.text:
he cured the man instantly of his paralysis.
My teacher in her message encouraged us to

1571.71.text:
make sure that we, too, had those stretcher
bearers in our lives, at least four people

1579.82.text:
who would carry us to healing and safety when
we can't do it for ourselves, the people who

1585.84.text:
remind you that you are not alone when your
emotions get the best of you.

1591.72.text:
Three. Ask questions of yourself, for yourself,
and listen out everywhere for yourself. Take

1599.72.text:
reading recommendations from people you respect.
It was in sitting in a talk‑back with a

1604.71.text:
documentary filmmaker that I learned about
the book, "Fight Your Fear and Win" by Don

1611.28.text:
Greene, and it literally got me out of my
crisis before I went to Yale.

1617.44.text:
That and the book, Map for Life, a life management
book by Dan McQuirk that my mother insisted

1623.63.text:
for five years that I read before I read it,
and I picked it up and I never regret it.

1629.54.text:
I go back to these books often.
Four. Do not underestimate the power of writing

1636.19.text:
your dreams and goals down. Right before I
got cast in 12 Years a Slave, I wrote in my

1642.63.text:
diary what kind of work I wanted to do. I
envisioned ‑‑ this was on May 4th, 2012 ‑‑

1652.26.text:
that I wanted to make meaningful films that
effect change and people's understanding of

1657.86.text:
and commitment to the world we live in. I
also wrote that I wanted to visit New Orleans

1666.01.text:
On May 13th I booked 12 Years a Slave, and
on June 6th I would be in Louisiana working

1672.40.text:
on the film for five weeks.
Five. Breathe. Meditate. Pray. Be still with

1682.20.text:
your soul. There is a force within us that
surrounds us, penetrates us, and binds us

1688.49.text:
together, and I'm not just saying that because
I am in Star Wars.

1695.90.text:
Six. Go for it! And always allow failure to
be an option. True freedom is being without

1705.55.text:
anxiety about imperfection, says Zen Master
Sang San. And right now I am learning to deeply

1713.76.text:
value my human right to be imperfect. No matter
who we are and what stage of achievement we

1720.34.text:
are at, I think it is healthy to always have
some perfection to work towards. It gives

1726.39.text:
us perspective and also gives us something
worth living another day for.

1734.19.text:
Seven. Finally, step forward and repeat it
all. With each step you take, with each new

1744.60.text:
challenge you face, expect yourself to learn
these lessons again and again. Do not be disappointed

1752.49.text:
in yourself when it feels like this time it
is harder, or different. It will always be

1757.86.text:
harder or different if you are growing! When
you feel overwhelmed by this, remind yourself

1765.38.text:
that you feel despair because you care. Step
and repeat. Step and repeat. It doesn't ever

1775.74.text:
get comfortable, but it does get familiar.
Thank you.
